entry.title: 2024 A Year In Review
entry.content:
üïí Estimated Read Time: 16 minutes

This year has been tremendous for me, with many unexpected changes‚Äîboth welcome and unwelcome. I was pushed to stop overthinking or planning too far ahead and instead focus on living in the moment, prioritizing what truly matters, addressing issues quickly, and leaving analysis and reflection for later. I was also fortunate to make a wonderful group of new friends, with whom I shared many enthusiastic and meaningful conversations. This helped me open my heart and become more open-minded. Looking back, I gained so much but also lost some. As we say in Chinese, what you gain is what you deserve, and what you lose is what was never meant to be yours. 2025, I am ready.

Life & Experience·°£ê≠©

The first and most meaningful experience this year was passing the CFA Level II exam in January. I cried and called my mom as soon as I saw the result. Thinking I had failed, she tried really hard to comfort me. Then I said, ‚ÄúNo, I passed! I‚Äôm just too thrilled.‚Äù The last time I cried like that was when I found out I got into my high school, lol. It wasn‚Äôt just about the exam result‚Äîit was about proving to myself that I can overcome challenges and accomplish difficult things. I deeply value the sense of achievement and personal growth that came from this journey, as it was rooted in self-reflection and mindfulness.

At the same time, I made an important decision to stop studying for Level III, as I‚Äôve decided not to pursue a career in finance in the foreseeable future. While the industry is undoubtedly attractive, I‚Äôve realized it‚Äôs not the right path for me. With this decision, I resumed studying data science, began practicing regularly, and started exploring ideas for data analysis projects on Kaggle.

I resumed traveling this year. My last job required me to travel frequently, and for a while, I thought it would be better to stay at home. However, I really enjoyed my trip to Vienna, which gave me the chance to unwind, especially when I met so many interesting people and experienced unexpected surprises. I still remember the photographer‚Äôs son, a stranger, and another little boy we met when she took a photo of me. A friend once told me that I always make new friends wherever I go.

Playing video games on a console was another new experience for me this year. I was under a lot of stress this Spring, and my friend convinced me to give video games a try. Initially, I was resistant, largely due to the toxic and ignorant mindset I‚Äôd encountered in the past, which labeled video games as pointless. But why must everything we do be meaningful? Who defines what is joyful? I ended up buying an Xbox Series S and subscribing to Xbox Game Pass for six months. Out of all the games I played, Assassin‚Äôs Creed Origins became my favorite, followed closely by Hitman 47 Deluxe Edition. I enjoy games that require strategy to outsmart enemies rather than just confronting and killing them‚Äîthis feels very much in line with my personality.

I started dating again and met my favorite person (so far). We‚Äôve had a lot of meaningful conversations, and he‚Äôs a great listener‚Äîat least, he tries to be open-minded. Together, we‚Äôve hunted for mini statues around Budapest and traveled as well. My friends said that being in a romantic relationship completely changed me from Amy to Bernadette. I laughed and refuted that, saying, ‚ÄúYou folks never knew me before, lol.‚Äù

The biggest (yet unexpected) takeaway this year was the positive decision regarding my permanent residence. I didn‚Äôt expect it to come so soon. Gaining PR has given me more vocational flexibility and the freedom to choose where I want to live.

Compared to the start of this year, I‚Äôm clearly happier (many thanks to my dearest friends again) and no longer feel the Sunday blues. I hope that next year, I can continue spending time with all these wonderful friends, enjoying good food, art, and museums together in Europe.

(Gosh, I still feel like I‚Äôll never finish this year-end review‚Ä¶)

Health & Lifestyle·°£ê≠©

I still felt stressed over low-probability things this year. First, I worried too much about my cavities, then about the potential failure of a dental surgery, even though I live in a city known as the dental capital of Europe. In the end, the surgery was very successful, and I didn‚Äôt even feel any pain after the anesthetic wore off (I‚Äôve started to appreciate local public care a bit more). Then, I spent a lot of time worrying about abdominal pain, which immediately cleared up when I went home for the holidays (probably caused by an unhealthy lifestyle). In early December, I worried excessively about another health issue, which turned out to be completely unfounded. All in all, my unhealthy lifestyle made me feel bad, which led to emotional stress and worsened the situation. I didn‚Äôt even realize this vicious cycle until I wrote it all down.

Eating and sleeping well remain a challenge for me, unfortunately. I‚Äôve kept up the bad habit of staying up late (sometimes all night), waking around noon, and repeating the cycle the next day. Because of this poor sleep routine, I often skip breakfast or even lunch, leaving me with just one meal most days. While I‚Äôm still young and healthy‚Äîonly catching one cold each winter and recovering without medication‚Äîthis lifestyle undoubtedly poses health risks if it continues. The only consolation is that my sleep quality is excellent. Once I‚Äôm asleep, I can easily enjoy 8+ uninterrupted hours. Still, I hope to adopt a better schedule, going to bed before 11 PM and waking up early around 7 AM.

In May, I had my annual health check and a few gynecological exams later in the year, all of which returned good results. It seems I‚Äôve inherited excellent genes from the women in my family. From discussions with my doctors, I‚Äôve learned that health is influenced most by family history, allergies, lifestyle choices (like coffee, smoking, and drinking), and exercise. I‚Äôm determined to keep up the positive habits.

This year, I didn‚Äôt develop a habit of frequent exercise. I‚Äôve lost the stamina to jog, which I used to have in my early 20s. To regain it, I started taking daily long walks, setting a calorie-burning goal on Apple Fitness. Some days it worked, and other days it didn‚Äôt, depending on how much free time I had or whether someone joined me. It also helped when there was an event to make the walk more engaging, rather than just random strolling. I particularly cherish moments of aimless chats with friends while walking along the Duna riverbank.

Body weight, along with BMI, is a reliable health indicator, and mine fluctuated a lot this year. After completing the CFA Level II exam, I indulged in Chinese restaurants, which led to weight gain. My weight peaked during my trip back to China, thanks to homemade food, bubble tea, snacks, and my grandma‚Äôs worry that I wasn‚Äôt eating well abroad. However, having my wisdom tooth removed forced a brief period of dietary restraint, and later, skipping meals helped me shed the extra pounds. Somehow, I managed to lose 33 pounds, reaching a relatively healthier BMI of 25.5.

New year, new me!

Mental & Emotion·°£ê≠©

As a typical HSP (Highly Sensitive Person), I tend to care too much about others and my environment, often at the expense of focusing on myself. I‚Äôm easily impacted by the words, facial expressions, and behaviors of those around me. I once thought it would be best to lock myself at home and focus solely on my own matters, but studying for an exam over the past two years only worsened the situation. Being isolated from society made me more sensitive and less sensible.

I sometimes wonder, am I really an introvert? I enjoy small-scale social events most of the time, and I‚Äôm energized by giving public speeches. My dark humor always makes people laugh (one friend even says his first amusement of the day always comes from my WeChat Moments #ÂæÆ‰ø°ÊúãÂèãÂúà). I took the MBTI test again and discovered that I‚Äôve shifted from ISTJ (the Logistician) to ENFJ (Protagonist). Interestingly, I often get different results depending on the language used for the test and my location, whether inside or outside China. Perhaps my friend, who is also an ENFJ, has influenced me as well.

Work brought me the most emotional turmoil this year: one was the unexpected team turnover, and the other was being forced to get involved in an unwanted task. My problem is that I can be too considerate and kind to people who don‚Äôt appreciate it. A man‚Äôs wealth is his own ruin by causing others‚Äô greed. I‚Äôm not the type to complain often, especially when all I want is emotional support. Once I start to repeat myself, it means I‚Äôm seeking a real solution and want to tackle the issue seriously. Through these two major situations, I realized that the best way for me to calm down is to do what I can, ask for help if necessary, and not to anticipate too much about the future. So, I‚Äôm learning to say no without feeling guilty, and I‚Äôve made two strides toward this at the end of the year. It was difficult when I was going through it, but later on, I felt no shame at all and thanked myself for that insistence. I may be slow to react, but I do react.

One positive change I experienced this year is that I finally admitted I‚Äôm one of the normal people who can sometimes feel or fear loneliness. In the past, I always denied its existence and judged others who acknowledged it or did silly things to cure their sense of loneliness. It‚Äôs okay to feel lonely, and I‚Äôm fortunate enough to have made many new friends with whom I‚Äôve had deep conversations. They‚Äôre like dandelion seeds, scattering in the backyard of my garden, bringing me endless joy.

They say that happiness comes from comparison, and I never doubted it. But with whom? One of my friends surprised me with his thoughts and made me feel guilty when he said he‚Äôs happy with his friends‚Äô success. He‚Äôs right. The true nobility lies in being superior to your previous self. Focusing too much on other people‚Äôs seemingly superior lives will only drown you. It‚Äôs just a landscape.

Interpersonal·°£ê≠©

My mom bought a new flat in the city, so this year I finally had the chance to spend plenty of quality time with my grandma. My grandma embodies all the amazing traits of her generation in China: sanguine, industrious, never complaining, and cherishing family. She is incredibly hardworking‚Äîwaking up at 5 AM to cook, waking me up for breakfast, washing all the dishes, hand-washing the clothes, walking out to buy groceries, and then continuing with the chores. In the evening, she heads out to the square for group dancing, where she effortlessly makes new friends. She‚Äôs so easygoing and resourceful‚Äîsometimes she ends up meeting new people by chance, and before we know it, both of us are getting to know the neighborhood in the most unexpected ways.

My grandma loves fried chicken (both wings and nuggets!), burgers, enjoys bubble tea, and loves walking and traveling. I took her on a short trip to a neighboring city where we hiked for two days, yet she remained energetic‚Äîgosh, she‚Äôs 81 years old! Still!

Besides, she has a great sense of boundaries and never judges or tries to control the way her kids and grandkids live. She understands that society is evolving quickly and admits that she might be a bit behind, so the best approach is to respect young people‚Äôs opinions and let them live their own way. And speaking of that, can you believe she‚Äôs illiterate and never had any formal education?

I wish I could have her passion and enthusiasm for life, facing challenges and defying turbulence in such a relentless way.

I met over 10 people this year, and among them, 6-7 became really close friends. I tried a live chat room but was quite disappointed by the Chinese guys there (arrogant as always). So, I moved to Bumble BFF mode and made a really good friend who even invited me to a Christmas party with locals only. The other friends I made came through networking‚Äîthis is the advantage of being around and knowing extroverts; you meet one, and you meet them all. I was so surprised that I made so many real friends and had quality time with them. I truly appreciate the time they spent with me. Let‚Äôs share love, care, and calories!

I‚Äôm still not the type of person who tends to confront conflicts. I filter people instead of giving lectures. However, I‚Äôve learned to react in the moment, rather than spending too much time reliving and analyzing a situation before responding. I admit that I place feelings ahead of judgment. In real-life experiences, I‚Äôve found that, in certain situations, I simply cannot speak freely around people I feel uneasy with. On the other hand, with people I feel comfortable around, I become more creative and my ideas flow. Acknowledging the existence of these vibes has made it much easier to make new friends. If someone makes me feel uncomfortable, I leave. I believe there will always be a comfort zone for me, rather than sticking with the wrong people.

Overall, the degree of mental conflicts has decreased a lot this year, perhaps because I made so many good friends, and their involvement in my life kept me too busy to dwell on unnecessary thoughts. To be honest, even when I was alone in the evenings, I found myself watching series recommended by my extroverted friends‚Ä¶

Mindset·°£ê≠©

One of the best mindsets I learned this year is to stop deliberately immersing myself in things of secondary importance and simply take action. From my childhood, I was always taught and disciplined to treat little things with great care, even when they were completely unnecessary. I used to plan perfectly before making any moves and once get sidetracked, trying to get back on track with the original plan. Now, I take the first step and adjust as progress unfolds. Practice is the best learning experience, and by doing so, I found that fears and anxieties disappeared, and what I once anticipated as insurmountable turned out to be not threatening at all. Also, the ‚Äúdo it for 5 minutes only‚Äù approach has been a great way to fight procrastination ‚Äî once I started, I found the task wasn‚Äôt troublesome at all, and I enjoyed it.

A similar thing this year is that I also confronted rumination and learned not to get lost in it. I used to believe every problem had to be solved, but after reading the book Overcoming Unwanted Intrusive Thoughts, I realized sometimes it‚Äôs just an intrusive thought, and the best thing to do is ignore it. Focusing on the present and what‚Äôs most important has made a big difference. With the help of pistachio ice cream, salami pizza, Thai massages, and spending time with my favorite person, I‚Äôve managed to unwind and stay relaxed. The power of rumination can be strong, and even though I tried, I still focused too much on bad memories. I‚Äôm still working hard to shake them off. Maybe this is a random walk, but as long as I keep walking, change will come.

Another mindset I like is not to fear bad things, as good things will follow to restore internal balance. I‚Äôm grateful for all the kind people I‚Äôve met this year ‚Äî you‚Äôve truly lit up my life.

Skillset & Learning curve·°£ê≠©

One of the best skills I learned this year was building this blog website using a blog framework, with the help of my friend Sam Li. Initially, I just wanted to create something fun because I enjoy coding and building new things. However, I never expected it to be so useful and to become one of my major achievements of the year. I motivated myself to have more inputs and outputs to showcase on the website, which became a strong driving force for creating more content. I also sought my friends‚Äô opinions and used their photos as illustrations, which helped me connect with them even more.

From a reading perspective, I finished 6 books this year and am still reading 2, all of which are fictional. Compared to over 30 books last year, this is still a lot, especially since one of the books I‚Äôm reading is extremely long (around 4 million Chinese characters, taking over 100 hours to finish). However, focusing solely on the number of books or hours doesn‚Äôt tell the full story.

The most valuable book I read this year was Did Miss Zhu Fall Into a Trap Today?, which I really enjoyed as a piece of electronic literature (ÁΩëÊñá). It‚Äôs an intriguing story about a woman who disguises herself as a man and thrives in a political environment where women are discouraged from receiving an education and are not allowed to work. She becomes a completely self-made woman and eventually rises to the position of prime minister. Once in power, she reveals her true identity as a woman, resigns, and becomes a landowner in one of the country‚Äôs regions. I was surprised by the quality of this literature and felt motivated by the protagonist‚Äôs journey. It reminded me that just getting started and focusing on solving problems can lead to transformative change.

I wanted to take more courses on Coursera, but due to some drama, my subscription was canceled. So, I went back to DataCamp for the Data Engineering and Data Science tracks. The engineering courses were quite boring, so I paused them and focused on the Data Science ones instead. These courses have been really helpful in building step-by-step knowledge, especially since I never learned Python systematically back in university. The courses, along with the practice sessions, allow me to learn from scratch and truly understand the ‚Äúhow‚Äù after grasping the ‚Äúwhat.‚Äù I love the sequence of learning lists, arrays, dictionaries, and data frames. I‚Äôm still struggling with slicing and selection, but I‚Äôm confident I‚Äôll get the hang of it soon. In the near future, I plan to leverage the databases on Kaggle and work on more data analysis projects, which I‚Äôll post on this website.

I have always been a huge fan of AI like ChatGPT, Claude, and Copilot, using them for refining my writing, fixing coding errors, scheduling my day, and more. Inspired by some Reddit users, I decided to create a digital version of myself. I input statistics about myself, including personality test results, life experiences, and key self-comments regarding important decisions in my life. Then, I trained the model and refined the outcome. This process allowed me to understand myself better by asking the model questions. There were many useful prompts that helped me gain insights, such as ‚Äúsum up my core question in life.‚Äù This aided in my self-reflection and provided direction for self-development, inspiring me to think in multiple directions. It‚Äôs not about finding a machine to replace my own thinking but rather finding a digital friend who can imitate my thought process and inspire deeper questions.

The last habit I developed is using Google Calendar to write my diary. I‚Äôve been journaling since I was five and always enjoyed it, but moving frequently made paper diaries impractical. After trying various tools like Evernote, Notion, Notability, and Apple Notes, I decided to simplify the process by using Google Calendar events to log my achievements. This way, I can combine what happened that day with my feelings in one place. It‚Äôs incredibly useful for writing my year-end review, as I can easily browse my calendar and read about what happened throughout the year.

The Personal Touch·°£ê≠©

  1. Snowuary·°£ê≠©

    Foggy Budapest, where I returned home after a solo celebration of my biggest exam success.

  2. Shortest Month·°£ê≠©

    My best friend Cat moved to the Netherlands, and we had our last Afternoon Tea at IKEA, a place we used to frequent a lot when we were both at university.

  3. Spring Awakens·°£ê≠©

    From my friend @j_s_joyce, who always takes amazing photos and now serves as my primary photographer for the website.

  4. Blossom Month·°£ê≠©

    Cotton candy in the sky.

  5. May Flowers·°£ê≠©

    Travelling with my grandma. My open-mindedness all comes from her.

  6. Longest Days·°£ê≠©

    Celebrating the Dragon Boat Festival with family‚Äînothing beats homemade food.

  7. Sunburst Month·°£ê≠©

    With Shengshifu (again)‚Äîcooking together is always a great way to strengthen friendships.

  8. Golden Summer·°£ê≠©

    A spontatenous trip to Vienna. I love the Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien and the ribs.

  9. Fall‚Äôs Whisper·°£ê≠©

    The parliament in the rain and flood. I started hunting for Mih√°ly Kolodko‚Äôs hidden mini statues.

  10. Crunchy Leaves·°£ê≠©

    A foodie‚Äôs year. I love this Vietnemese restaurant.

  11. Frosty Mornings·°£ê≠©

    On All Saints‚Äô Day, Shengshifu and I climbed Normafa and watched the sunset. We hopped on the little train, and I ended up bruising my knees, lol.

  12. Holiday Cheer·°£ê≠©

At a corporate dinner, my old team invited me to gather before Christmas. That night, we enjoyed some great ginger palinka together.

First and foremost, I give all credits of this website building to my study partner OLC who has always encouraged me to buid my own zone and offered treemendous help in initiating, testing, and wrapping up the first version of this website. @OLC, Thanks so much! without you, this personal blogging would just be a blueprint with no progress.
